headline: Canada Mostly Spared From Reciprocal Tariffs, But Shouldn’t Grow Complacent | OPINION - U of G News
context: By Dr. Sylvanus Kwaku Afesorgbor, professor, Ontario Agricultural College, University of Guelph
This article is republished from The Conversation Canada under a Creative Commons licence. Read the original article.

annotations.paragraph: United States President Donald Trump’s so-called Liberation Day introduced sweeping reciprocal tariffs on approximately 60 countries on April 2.
annotations.reason: Provides context about the introduction of tariffs relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Canada, a major U.S. trading partner, was largely spared from these reciprocal tariffs thanks to the Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA) — a free trade agreement renegotiated and signed by the Trump administration in 2020.
annotations.reason: Explains why Canada was mostly spared from the tariffs, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Although it may appear Canada has avoided the worst of the tariff measures, other existing tariffs could still significantly impact Canadian trade with the U.S.
annotations.reason: Highlights potential ongoing impacts of tariffs on Canadian trade, relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: Currently, Canada faces other tariffs on its exports to the U.S., which Trump has linked to concerns over illicit drugs and immigrants crossing the border. Under these measures, the U.S. has imposed a 25 per cent tariff on non-CUSMA compliant goods. Canadian energy and potash exports that are not CUSMA-compliant have been hit with a 10 per cent tariff.
annotations.reason: Details specific tariffs affecting Canadian exports, relevant to the article's focus on trade impacts.

annotations.paragraph: If the current tariffs related to fentanyl and migration are lifted, CUSMA-compliant goods would continue to enjoy preferential treatment, while non-compliant goods would then be subject to a 12 per cent reciprocal tariff.
annotations.reason: Discusses potential future changes in tariff conditions, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Under CUSMA, a product is considered compliant if it originates from any of the three member countries: Canada, the U.S. or Mexico. This means the product satisfies the originating status according to the rules of origin criteria listed in the CUSMA agreement.
annotations.reason: Provides essential context about CUSMA compliance relevant to the topic of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: To be deemed originating, some of the criteria includes, for instance:
annotations.reason: Introduces criteria for originating status but lacks specific details or relevance to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Regional value content is the difference between the transaction value of a product adjusted for costs related to international shipping of the good, and the value of non-originating material. It is expressed as a percentage of the transaction value.
annotations.reason: Explains a specific criterion for originating status, providing detailed context relevant to CUSMA compliance.

annotations.paragraph: When a product qualifies for an originating status, it is considered CUSMA-compliant. It then qualifies for a preferential treatment, which means it can enter the CUSMA market duty-free or at a reduced rate.
annotations.reason: Explains the benefits of CUSMA compliance, directly relevant to the topic of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Under the CUSMA tariff schedule, which outlines tariff commitments on Canadian products, the vast majority of Canadian exports to the U.S. are eligible for preferential treatment.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about Canadian exports and their eligibility for preferential treatment under CUSMA.

annotations.paragraph: In fact, more than 98 per cent of tariff lines and more than 99.9 per cent of bilateral trade are CUSMA-compliant, meaning Canadian exporters can claim preferential access if their products meet the agreement’s rules of origin.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data on CUSMA compliance relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Based on the Tariff Schedule of the United States, 98.4 per cent of Canadian products enter the U.S. duty-free, while only 1.6 per cent face tariffs. These protected products are primarily agricultural goods considered sensitive by the U.S. — notably dairy and sugar.
annotations.reason: Offers detailed information on tariff-free access and exceptions, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: These protected items are typically subject to tariff rate quotas, which allow limited quantities to enter at a lower (within-quota) duty rate, while imports beyond the quota are permitted at a higher (over-quota) tariff rate.
annotations.reason: Explains tariff rate quotas, providing context for the exceptions mentioned.

annotations.paragraph: Although Canada was not directly targeted by Trump’s reciprocal tariffs, its steel and aluminum industries remains significantly impacted by Section 232 tariffs. Importantly, these tariffs cannot be waived due to CUSMA.
annotations.reason: Discusses the impact of Section 232 tariffs on Canada, directly relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 authorizes the U.S. president to restrict the import of certain goods if they threaten national security. Under this provision, the Trump administration has imposed a 25 per cent duty on steel, aluminum and related products.
annotations.reason: Provides context on Section 232 tariffs, relevant to the impact on Canada.

annotations.paragraph: Steel and aluminum products are crucial to Canada, with total exports of iron and steel, iron or steel products and aluminum products reaching $34.8 billion in 2024. It’s hard to imagine the U.S. justifying tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum on national security grounds, given Canada’s longstanding role as one of its closest allies.
annotations.reason: Provides relevant context about the importance of steel and aluminum exports to Canada and the improbability of U.S. tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: The automotive sector has also been targeted with the Section 232 tariffs. As Canada’s second-largest export to the U.S., valued at over $72.3 billion in 2024, the industry relies heavily on an integrated cross-border supply chain. That makes the sector particularly vulnerable to tariffs.
annotations.reason: Highlights the vulnerability of Canada's automotive sector to tariffs, relevant to the article's focus on trade issues.

annotations.paragraph: The imposition of a 25 per cent tariff on non-U.S. content in vehicles threatens the profitability of Canadian producers and reduces production efficiency.
annotations.reason: Discusses the impact of tariffs on Canadian automotive producers, directly related to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Determining non-U.S. content at the border will lead to significant inefficiencies, including long wait times, as companies attempt to prove American content in vehicles. This process will also demand an excessive amount of documentation, imposing unnecessary costs on businesses.
annotations.reason: Explains the logistical challenges and costs associated with the tariffs, relevant to the article's discussion on trade impacts.

annotations.paragraph: This tariff also undermines CUSMA’s rules of origin, which allow vehicles with at least 75 per cent North American content to qualify for duty-free access. The Section 232 measure effectively penalizes compliant vehicles, creating a trade barrier inconsistent with the spirit of the agreement.
annotations.reason: Describes how the tariffs conflict with existing trade agreements, relevant to the article's focus on trade issues.

annotations.paragraph: The uncertainty created by the Trump administration’s unilateral trade policies poses a serious threat to Canada and the global economy as a whole. With Trump’s presidency just beginning, both Canada and the rest of the world must brace for the economic disruptions his policies may bring.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the potential impact of Trump's trade policies on Canada and the global economy.

annotations.paragraph: At the bilateral level, Canada appears to have exhausted nearly all diplomatic avenues to persuade the Trump administration to reverse its harmful tariff measures. Regionally, while Trump renegotiated the CUSMA agreement, his actions have undermined its spirit and violated key provisions.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses Canada's diplomatic efforts and the impact of Trump's actions on trade agreements.

annotations.paragraph: At the multilateral level, the World Trade Organization (WTO) has been significantly weakened. Its dispute settlement mechanism has been rendered ineffective due to the U.S. blocking the appointment of new judges to its appellate body.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on the weakening of the WTO and its implications for global trade.

annotations.paragraph: The only faint silver lining is that, despite threats during his first term to withdraw from the organization, Trump has not followed through. This suggests he still holds at least some degree of respect or recognition for the WTO’s role in global trade.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers insight into Trump's stance on the WTO, relevant to the trade context.

annotations.paragraph: The world is currently navigating a period of deep uncertainty and confusion. Canada must stand in solidarity with the international community to exert collective pressure on the U.S. A co-ordinated global response could compel Trump to reconsider his unilateral trade policies.
annotations.reason: This paragraph suggests a strategy for Canada and the international community to address trade policy challenges.

annotations.paragraph: Although Canada has been granted a reprieve from the new reciprocal tariffs, this should not lead to complacency. Instead, Canada should continue to collaborate with other nations to push for a more stable and rules-based global trading system. This is the way to protect Canada’s interests and reinforce multilateral co-operation.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides relevant commentary on Canada's position regarding reciprocal tariffs and suggests actions to maintain its trade interests.
